Departamento de Ingeniería Química y Bioprocesos Escuela de Ingeniería Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile Avenida Vicuña Mackenn 4860 Macul Santiago Chile Graphical abstract The conversion of levulinic acid over rhenium oxide catalysts supported on ZrO2 and SiO2 in a batch reactor at 200 °C and 5 MPa of H2 pressure was studied. The catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation with nominal loadings of 5–18 wt.%. The catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption, field emission scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, H2-temperature programmed reduction, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The catalysts were highly active and selective to γ-valerolactone. Catalytic activity, expressed as initial reaction rate and based on catalyst weight, was correlated with dispersion. The difference in the activity trend was attributed to ReOx-support interaction: ZrO2 interacted more strongly with ReOx and modified the electronic character of the sites, whereas SiO2 interacted weakly with ReOx, leading to unmodified Re active sites, irrespective of Re loading. All the catalysts exceeded 90 % selectivity to GVL. Keywords Biomass Levulinic acid Rhenium oxide catalysts γ-Valerolactone 1 Introduction Depleting fossil resources and increasing concerns about greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions have led to global efforts on finding cleaner and abundant alternative energy sources. Lignocellulosic biomass offers potential benefits to petroleum as an alternative carbon source [1] because it is cheap, abundant and available worldwide [2,3]. Furthemore, lignocellulosic biomass is sustainable and its derivatives can be transformed into fuels and many valuable chemicals [4–13]. For this reason, it is predicted that 20 % of transportation fuels and 25 % of chemicals will be produced from lignocellulosic biomass by 2030 [14]. The conversion of biomass to platform chemicals with broad applications has attracted a great deal of attention in the last years. One of these platform chemicals, levulinic acid (LA), has been identified by the United States Department of Energy as one of the ten high-value biomass-derived compounds due to its reactive nature [15–17]. Moreover, it can be easily and economically produced from lignocellulosic wastes through selective chemical transformations using a conventional hydrolysis process [18]. Levulinic acid has also been identified as a key intermediate for the conversion of non-edible biomass to fuels and chemicals [19–28]. For example, LA can be converted to γ-valerolactone (GVL), one of the most important platform chemicals and a precursor to biofuels [24,29–34]. This compound has widespread application, including its use as food additive, green solvent in ﬁne chemical synthesis, and as a precursor to fuel additives and bulk polymers [35–39]. The catalytic conversion of LA has received considerable attention, and the subject has been reviewed recently by Obregón and coworkers [40]. In general, the transformation occurs via two pathways: (1) hydrogenation of the ketone group of LA to form an unstable intermediate, 4-hydroxypentanoic acid, and subsequent intramolecular esterification that results in ring closure to produce GVL, and (2) dehydration of LA to α-angelica lactone (α-AL), followed by hydrogenation to GVL. The produced GVL can be hydrogenated to 1.4-pentanediol (1.4-PDO), which can then be dehydrated to 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF) [26,32,40,41]. Heterogeneous catalysts have been widely employed for the conversion of LA to GVL, particularly noble metals (Ru, Pd, Ir, Rh and Au) and non-noble metals (Cu, Ni, Mg and Al) catalysts [17,41–44]. An overview of the performance of the noble metals and non-nobles metals catalysts used for the conversion of LA to GVL is presented in Table S1 (supplementary material). The supported noble metals catalysts, such us Ru and Pd, presented good catalytic performances in the conversion of LA to GVL [14,25], but they are relatelively expensive. Thus, the search for non-noble metal alternatives is desirable. However, as shown in Table S1, the non-noble metal-based catalysts were not as effective. Therefore, it is desirable to explore non-traditional choices, such us supported rhenium catalysts. These catalysts have been found to be particularly effective for the selective conversion of biomass derivatives, including guaiacol, phenol, anisole, and furfural [45–61]. The studies utilized various active phases of rhenium, including as a metal, an oxide, and a sulfide, demonstrating its general suitability for converting bio-oil derived compounds. Rhenium in its oxide state has shown the most promise which has been attributed to its electron-deficient state under reaction conditions, promoting direct cleavage of CO bonds [30]. In the present work, rhenium oxide catalysts have been used for the conversion of LA. The catalysts were prepared with different loadings and supported on ZrO2 and SiO2. The selection of these supports was based on the fact that both have Brønsted acid sites with different strengths [23,53,56,62]. Thus, the objective of this study is to identify properties that control reactivity, which can then serve as descriptors for the preparation of improved catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of SiO2 and ZrO2 supports using an aqueous solution of ammonium perrhenate (NH4ReO4, 99 %, Sigma-Aldrich). SiO2 (Silica Grace 432) was obtained commercially, whereas ZrO2 was prepared in house by calcining zirconium (IV) oxide (Zr(OH)4, 97 % Sigma Aldrich) at 300 °C for 1 h. After the impregnation, the samples were kept at room temperature for 24 h, dried at 110 °C for 12 h, and calcined at 300 °C for 0.5 h, both in air. The samples, with nominal loadings ranging from 5 to 18 wt.% on SiO2 and 5 to 15 wt.% on ZrO2, were sieved to 100−140 μm. The catalysts were denoted as ReOx(x)/support, where the x in parenthesis represents Re loading in wt.%, as shown in Table 1 . Additionally, Table 1 shows the equivalence of the weight percentage in atoms per nm2 of support. 2.2 Characterization of supports and catalysts Nitrogen physisorption measurements were carried out at 196 °C using a Micromeritics 3Flex instrument. Prior to the analyses, the samples (50 mg) were degassed at 200 °C for 3 h using a Micromeritics SmartVacPrep device. Surface areas (SBET) were calculated from the linear range (0.05 ≤ P/P0 ≤ 0.25) of the adsorption isotherm using the BET model [63]. Total pore volumes (Vp) were recorded at a relative pressure (P/P0) of 0.99, and average pore diameters were estimated from the desorption isotherm using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda method (BJH) [64]. Elemental composition and surface distribution of the active phase were determined by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) using an electron microscope (Quanta FEG 250) equipped with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). Crystalline phase identification and crystallite size determination were performed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Bruker AXS D4 Endeavor diﬀ ;ractometer equipped with a nickel-ﬁltered CuKα1 radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The standard scan parameters were 10−90 ° 2θ with a step size of 0.02 ° and a counting time of 0.4 s per step. Identiﬁcation of the phases were achieved by reference to ICDD data files. The crystallites size was calculated using the Scherrer equation [65]. Reducibility of the samples was analyzed by H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) using a Micromeritics 3Flex instrument coupled to a mass spectrometer (Cirrus 2, MKS Spectra Procuct) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Samples (15−20 mg) were loaded into a quartz reactor tube and heated from room temperature to 1000 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 in a 5 % H2-Ar flow (100 mL min-1). The effluent gas was passed through a cold trap immersed in a mixture of isopropanol and liquid nitrogen before entering the mass spectrometer and TCD detector. The mass signal corresponding to water (m/z = 18) was monitored, although the presented reduction profiles were obtained from calibrated TCD signals. Surface acidity measurements were performed by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine. Spectra were recorded using a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS10 spectrometer equipped with a heatable and evacuatable reaction cell with CaF2 windows, which was connected to gas-dosing and evacuation systems. The powdered samples (50 mg) were pressed into self-supporting wafers with a diameter of 20 mm. The samples were pretreated at 300 °C for 30 min and cooled to room temperature, both in air, before measurements. Pyridine was then introduced to the sample at room temperature until saturation. The adsorption spectra (2 cm−1 resolution, 100 scans) were recorded at room temperature after removing the gas phase by evacuation, and at different temperatures during heating under helium flow. Surface analysis was performed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements using a VG Escalab 200R electron spectrometer fitted with a Mg Kα (1253.6 eV) photon source. The binding energies (BE) were referenced to the C 1s level at 284.8 eV. An estimated error of ± 0.1 eV can be assumed for all measurements. Intensities of the peaks were estimated by calculating the peak areas after background subtraction and smoothing. The spectra were fitted by a standard computer-based statistical analysis which included fitting of the experimental curve to a combination of Gaussian/Lorentzian lines (90 % Guassian-10 % Lorentzian) using a least squares minimization procedure for χ2 with the help of the XPS peak software. Relative surface atomic ratios were determined from peak areas, normalized based on acquisition parameters, sensitivity and transmission factors provided by the manufacturer, with a precision of 7 %. 2.3 Catalytic reaction tests Conversion of levulinic acid was performed in an autoclave reactor operating in batch mode (Parr model 4848) at 200 °C under a hydrogen pressure of 5 MPa for 3 h. The liquid reactant feed consisted of levulinic acid (Acros Organics, 98 %) and hexadecane (internal standard, Sigma Aldrich, 99 %) dissolved in 80 mL of 1,4-dioxane (Across Organics, 99 %). 1,4 dioxane was selected as the solvent because levulinic acid is soluble in this reagent. In addition, its vapor pressure at the temperature of the reaction is adequate [20,29,66]. The concentration of levulinic acid was 0.232 mol L−1 and that of hexadecane was 0.0341 mol L−1. An amount of calcined catalyst (200 mg) was added to the mixture in the reactor, which was then closed and flushed with N2 (Indura, 99.995 %) for 10 min to evacuate air from the system. The reactor was heated to 200 °C in N2 under continuous stirring. The experimental conditions were chosen in order to operate under a regime not limited by mass transfer [53]. The reaction was assumed to start at 200 °C since reactivity under N2 below 200 °C was negliglible. The pressure was adjusted to 5 MPa by introducing H2. Condensed samples were taken periodically and identified by gas chromatography (Shimadzu, GC-2030), equipped with a Flame Ionization Detector (FID) and a CP-Sil 5 column (Agilent, 30 m×0.53 mm ×1.0 μm ﬁlm thickness). The products were identified by their column retention time in comparison with standards. The conversion of LA (XLA%) and selectivity (S%) were determined by Eqs. (1) and (2) as follows: (1) X L A m o l % = n L A 0 - n L A i n L A o x 100 (2) S m o l % = n p r o d u c t j n L A c o n v e r t e d x 100 In these equations, n L A 0 is the initial moles of LA in the feed (mol), n L A i is the moles of LA at time i (mol), n p r o d u c t j is the moles of product j and n L A c o n v e r t e d is that of LA converted. The selectivity (S %) was calculated at an LA conversion of 30 %. Catalytic activity was expressed by the initial reaction rate rs (mol g−1 s−1), based on the mass of the catalyst, and the intrinsic rate (ri ), based on exposed rhenium species determined from XPS results. The initial reaction rate was calculated from the initial slope of the conversion versus time plot according to Eq. (3): (3) r s = [ b x n L A 0 ] m Here, b represents the initial slope of the conversion vs. time plot (s−1), n is the initial moles of LA in the solution (mol), and m is the mass of the catalyst. The intrinsic rate (molecules of levulinic acid converted per exposed surface rhenium atom per second and expressed in molecLAatomRe −1s−1) was calculated by (Eq. (4) according to Toledo et al. [67]. (4) r i = r s × M W s u p p o r t 1 - W t R e × R e / Z r ( S i ) X P S In this equatioin, r s is initial reaction rate (mol g−1 s−1), MWsupport is the molar mass of the support, WtRe is the Re loading (in wt%), and R e / Z r ( S i ) X P S is atomic ratio (atom atom−1) obtained from XPS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization BET surface area (SBET), total pore volume (Vp), and pore diameter (dp) of the supports and as-prepared catalysts are summarized in Table 1. The SBET of the ZrO2-supported samples ranged from 129 to 161 m2 g−1 and that of the SiO2-supported samples ranged from 260 to 350 m2 g−1. Correspondingly, the VP of the former ranged from 0.17 to 0.25 cm3 g−1 and that of the latter ranged from 0.88 to 1.27 cm3 g−1. As expected, SBET and VP decreased with increasing Re loading. The SBET and VP decreased only slightly after impregnation of rhenium on to the ZrO2 support, suggesting that blockage of the mouth of the pores was negligible. This is consistent with a homogeneous deposition of rhenium oxide species in the pores of the ZrO2 support and is in agreement with the similar N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the catalysts (Fig. S1 in the supplementary information (SI)). On the other hand, the decrease of the surface area and pore volume of the SiO2 support after impregnation of rhenium oxide was more profound, probably due to partial pore blockage. The surface metal distribution of the catalysts was determined by FESEM and shown in Figs. 1 and 2 . Two samples (ReOx(5)/ZrO2 and ReOx(10)/SiO2) with the same number of metal atoms per nm2 of initial support area (1.0 atoms nm−2 of support) were used here as representative samples. It can be seen that rhenium species were uniformly distributed on the surface of both supports, although ReOx(10)/SiO2 showed a small degree of agglomeration. Nevertheless, the results are consistent with a more homogeneous distribution of ReOx species on ZrO2 than on SiO2, in agreement with deductions from N2 physisorption results. X-ray diffraction patterns of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 3 . The patterns for ReOx(x)/ZrO2 (Fig. 3a) and ReOx(x)/SiO2 (Fig. 3b) catalysts show diffraction peaks corresponding to NH4ReO4 − [46,53]. However, the presence of ReO3 in both catalysts cannot be ruled out because it presents nearly identical diffraction pattern as NH4ReO4, as noted by Toledo et al. [53]. The presence of NH4ReO4 can be explained by an incomplete decomposition of the precursor salt due to the mild calcination conditions (300 °C for 0.5 h). However, this condition was necessary to prevent sublimation of rhenium, as reported by Reyes et al. [68]. Moreoever, previous studies have demonstrated that complete decomposition of NH4ReO4 occurs under reaction conditions similar to those used in this study [56,57]. From Fig. 3, two main observations can be made. First, crystallinity of NH4ReO4 increased in the samples with increasing loading, as expected for samples prepared by impregnation. The second is that ReOx(x)/SiO2 samples (Fig. 3b) exhibited a higher degree of crystallinity than ReOx(x)/ZrO2 samples (Fig. 3a). This is evident when samples of identical surface metal density were compared: for example, although ReOx(10)/SiO2 and ReOx(5)/ZrO2 have the same surface rhenium density (1.0 atoms nm -2) the diffraction pattern of the former shows more distinct NH4ReO4 peaks. The difference is likely related to the strength of interaction between NH4ReO4 species and the supports, whereby the weak interaction of the precursor species and SiO2 promoted particle agglomeration (crystallite size calculated by the Scherrer equation was 31 nm, Table 1). These results are consistent with the observations from the FESEM results. Furthermore, Table 1 shows the crystallite size of the ReOx(x)/ZrO2 and ReOx(x)/SiO2 catalysts, calculated using the Scherrer equation [65]. As expected, a gradual increase in crystallites size is observed, with the increasing of the Re loading on the support. Temperature-programmed reduction profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 a and b. The profiles of ReOx(x)/ZrO2 (Fig. 4a) show two distinct peaks, the intensities and reduction temperatures of which vary with rhenium loading. Reduction profiles of reference samples (insert of Fig. 4a) indicate that the higher temperature peak corresponds to the reduction of NH4ReO4 while the lower temperature peak relates to the reduction of ReOx, prepared by calcining NH4ReO4 at 300 °C for 0.5 h. These results are consistent with previous findings [46,56,57] and suggest that both types of Re species exist on the ReOx(x)/ZrO2 catalysts. The reduction profiles of the ReOx(x)/SiO2 samples show two well-defined peaks for the samples with low to intermediate loadings. However, the lower-temperature peak disappears in the profiles of ReOx(15)/SiO2 and ReOx(18)/SiO2. This suggests a single reduction step and the existence of one type of Re species (ReOx) in the samples, in agreement with previous findings by Leiva et al. [56]. It is notable that for both ReOx(x)/ZrO2 and ReOx(x)/SiO2 systems, there is an obvious shift to lower reduction temperature with increasing loading. This behavior indicates that larger particles interact more weakly with supports, in agreement with previous work by Arnoldy et al. [69]. The reduction profiles of samples with the same surface metal density (1.0 atoms nm−2) are compared to explore the effect of support and are shown in Fig. 5 . The samples, ReOx(5)/ZrO2 and ReOx(10)/SiO2, show similar reduction profiles but clear differences in reduction temperatures: ReOx(10)/SiO2 is reduced at lower temperatures than ReOx(5)/ZrO2, in line with the differences in crystallite sizes that were noted earlier. This result shows a clear influence of the support on the physical properties of the rhenium species. As will be explained subsequently, surface acidity of the support may be responsible for the level of interaction and the concomitant differences in crystallite size and reduction temperature. The nature of the acid sites on the calcined ReOx(x)/ZrO2 and ReOx(x)/SiO2 catalysts were determined by FTIR spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine, and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . The bands were assigned according to previous reports by Busca and Glazunov [70,71]. As can be seen the bands corresponding to Brønsted (protonation) acid sites (1538 and 1633 cm−1) were not present on the bare ZrO2 and SiO2 supports and on the low-loading catalysts. These results indicate that Re impregnation of the materials created new Brönsted sites on the catalysts, in agreement with previous reports [26,72]. In addition, based on semi-quantitative analysis, the amount of acid sites on the ZrO2 support catalysts was larger than the ZrO2-supported counterparts (note the difference in the scale of the intensities). The strength of the acid sites was determined by heating the samples with pyridine adsorbed at room temperature in a flow of He ( Fig. 7 ). The spectra of two samples with the same metal surface density are shown here for comparison. The intensities of all the bands decreased with increasing temperature. However, whereas there were still observable bands on ReOx(5)/ZrO2 at 200 °C, there were no visible bands on ReOx(10)/SiO2 at 200 °C. This suggests that acidic sites on ReOx(5)/ZrO2 were stronger than those on ReOx(10)/SiO2, which could be due to a stronger interaction of ReOx with ZrO2 than with SiO2. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy measurements were performed on ReOx(x)/ZrO2 and ReOx(x)/SiO2 catalysts to obtain information on Re/Zr (Si) atomic ratios and oxidation states of species present. The Re 4f core-level spectra of ReOx(x)/ZrO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 . Curve fitting of the spectra revealed two partially overlapping doublets, each containing sub-peaks of Re 4f7/2 and Re 4f5/2. The Re 4f core-level spectra of ReOx(x)/SiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 9 . The decomposition of the spectra showed only one contribution in the form of a doublet (Re 4f7/2 and Re 4f5/2). The binding energies (BE) of the most intense Re 4f7/2 component of each 4f doublet, along with the Re/Zr(Si) surface atomic ratios, are summarized in Table 2 . The ReOx(x)/ZrO2 catalysts exhibited two Re 4f7/2 contributions with BE at 44.8 ± 0.1 eV assigned to Re+6 (ReO3) and 46.2 ± 0.1 eV due to Re+7 (Re2O7 or ReO4 −) [34,44]. The ReOx(x)/SiO2 samples presented one Re 4f7/2 contribution with BE of 46.4 ± 0.1 eV, close to values reported for Re+7 (Re2O7 or ReO4 −) [56,73]. These results are consistent with determinations from H2-TPR that two types of Re species are present on ReOx(x)/ZrO2 and one type of Re species is mainly present on ReOx(x)/SiO2 catalyst. The surface Re/Zr atomic ratio for ReOx(x)/ZrO2 listed in Table 2 and shown in Fig. 10 a increased linearly with Re loading up to 12 wt.%, and then deviated slighltly from linearity at 15 wt.%. The surface Re/Si atomic ratio for ReOx(x)/SiO2 summarized in Table 2 and depicted in Fig. 10b also increased linearly with Re loading up to 15 wt.%, and subsequently decreased at 18 wt.%. These results suggest a homogeneous distribution of the rhenium oxide active phase on the support, up to 12 wt.% Re on ZrO2 support and 15 wt.% Re on SiO2. The deviation from linearity at the highest Re content could be due to formation of agglomerates, and is consistent with reults from Toledo et al. [53]. 3.2 Catalytic activity The yield of products and conversion of levulinic acid as a function of time over the ReOx(5)/ZrO2 and ReOx(10)/SiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 11 . Results for only these two catalysts are shown here for brevity since the reactivity trends for all catalysts within one series are similar (the results for the other catalysts are shown in Figs. S3 and S4). The figures show that LA was converted primarily to γ-valerolactone (GVL) during the course of the reaction. A small amount of 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF) was observed. Furthermore, a small amount of 1.4-pentanediol (1.4-PDO) was detected at high conversion on the ReOx(10)/SiO2 catalyst. The proposed reaction scheme for the conversion of LA, depicted in Fig. 12 , is well-established in the literature and is used here to explain the reaction profiles [21,22,40,74]. Conversion of LA proceeds initially through two pathways. The first involves dehydration to form α-angelicalactone and hydrogenation to produce GVL. The second involves hydrogenation to form 4-hydroxypentanoic acid and dehydration to produce GVL. Subseqent steps include hydrogenation of GVL to form 1.4-PDO, followed by dehydration to form 2-MTHF. Since 4-hydroxypentanoic acid was not detected and α-angelicalactone (α-AL) was dectected in trace amount, it is likely that the secondary steps occur quickly under this condition. Other studies have also reported similar observations [16,32]. The activity as a function of Re loading is expressed as initial rate and the results are shown in Fig. 13 . For the ReOx(x)/ZrO2 catalysts, the rate went through a maximum at a Re content of 12 wt.%, and decreased at the highest loading studied in this work (Fig. 13a). Similarly, for the ReOx(x)/SiO2 catalysts, the rate increased up to a Re content of 15 wt.%, and decreased subsequently (Fig. 13b). The reactivity trend for both series follows the surface coverage of Re on the support determined by XPS. Thus, the increase in rate with loading can be explained by an increase in the amount of exposed Re species, whereas the subsequent decrease at the highest loading can be attributed to loss of active sites due to the formation of aggregates. Similar reactivity trends have previously been observed for the conversion of guaiacol [56] and furfural [53] over ReOx(x)/SiO2. The reactivity was also expressed as intrinsic rate based on surface Re/Zr and Re/Si atomic ratios measured by XPS. The results for ReOx(x)/ZrO2 (Fig. 14 a) show a slight decrease of the intrinsic rate with increasing Re content. In contrast, the intrinsic rate on ReOx(x)/SiO2 (Fig. 14b) appears to be insensitive to Re loading, indicating that the active sites were not affected by the support. This reflects differences between the two systems, a likely consequence of the nature of support. Characterization results indicate differences in structural and compositional properties between these two catalytic systems. It is notable that the intrinsic rates of ReOx(x)/SiO2 is an order of magnitude higher than those of ReOx(x)/ZrO2. This behavior suggests that the ReOx species supported over SiO2 presented a higher number of active sites than the ReOx species over ZrO2 support. This is likely related to the support and its possible influence on particle size and accessibility of ReOx sites to the reaction. In this sense, Cao et al. [75] reported the existence of structure-sensitivity in LA conversion over carbon- and alumina-supported Ru nanoparticles. Ruppert et al. [76] reported dependence of LA conversion over carbon-supported Ru catalysts, with the dependency being exclusive for very small particle size [76]. In the case of rhenium oxides, a correlation between particle size and structure has not been found. Furthermore, the crystallites size of rhenium is around of 35 nm, as indicated by XRD results. Previous works on ReOx catalysts for hydrogenation/hydrodeoxygenation reactions provide insights into the origin of the activity trend. Leiva et al. [57] reported that the active sites on ReOx species were oxygen vacancies created during in situ partial reduction by hydrogen during guaiacol conversion. The same conclusion was reached by Toledo et al. [53] for furfural conversion on ReOx/SiO2. The creation of oxygen vacancy sites on ReOx was confirmed on MoOx-ReOx/SiO2 catalysts using electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) analysis by Herrera et al. [46] for phenol conversion. Based on these studies, it is suggested that oxygen vacancy sites (on ReOx) played an important role for LA conversion. It is notable that the intrinsic rates of ReOx(x)/SiO2 is an order of magnitude higher than those of ReOx(x)/ZrO2 (note the difference in scale). This may be related to compositional differences or modification of ReOx species, induced by the strength of the acid sites on the support. The intrinsic activity results suggest that the creation of vacancy sites was not affected by the SiO2 support, irrespective of rhenium loading. On the other hand, the generation of active sites appeared to decrease with Re loading on the ZrO2 support. The XPS results showed larger surface coverage of ReOx on ZrO2 in the ReOx/ZrO2 catalysts than on SiO2 in the ReOx/SiO2 catalysts, indicating that ZrO2 stabilized ReOx species on the surface. This interpretation is in accordance with the observed ReOx-support interaction from TPR result, which showed that ReOx species were reduced at higher temperature on ZrO2 than on SiO2 with the same surface rhenium density (1.0 atoms nm−2). As previously discussed, the stronger ReOx–ZrO2 interaction could be attributed to the higher acid strength observed by pyridine FTIR, in accordance with findings by Arlondy et al. [69] and Mitra et al. [77]. Thus, the stronger interaction between ReOx and ZrO2, suggested by XPS and TPR, modified the electronic properties of Re and decreased the formation of vacancies. It is reasoned that this hampered the adsorption of LA adsorption on active sites. Unfortunately, XPS does not show electronic changes to Re7+ due to influence of support. In contrast, XPS shows that ZrO2 support stabilized the formation of Re6+ produced after calcination. The formation of Re6+ has been previously reported on more acidic supports such as Al2O3 and SiO2-Al2O3 [67]. It is conceivable that stronger interaction between ReOx and ZrO2, as discussed previously, impacted the electronic character of the active sites. This modification intensified with increasing rhenium content. In general, the results indicate that Re active sites that exist on SiO2 are intrinsically more active than those prevalent on ZrO2. This difference in behavior between the two systems could be due to the level of interaction of Re species with the support, which suggests that ReOx had a higher possibility of vacancy formation on SiO2 support during the initial stage of the reaction. On the other hand, the effect of the initial concentration (3 times) of LA on the most active catalyst Re(10)/SiO2 was studied and the result is shown in Fig. S5. It can be observed that the catalyst exhibited a decrease in its initial activity when the concentration of LA was increased, which can be attributed to saturation due to strong adsorption of LA on the active sites. The selectivity calculated at 30 % conversion of LA are shown in Fig. 15 . The catalysts presented similar products distribution, regardless of loading and support. The main product was GVL, with selectivity exceeding 90 % over most of the catalysts. The Lewis and Brønsted acid sites observed in the ReOx(x)/ZrO2 and ReOx(x)/SiO2 catalysts could have been responsible for the high selectivity to GVL, in agreement with previous studies [41,72]. However, the low amount of GVL derivatives indicates low activity for ring-opening reaction. This is not surprising as this step is favored mainly on catalysts with stronger acid sites. There was no significant difference in product selectivity, which is linked to the identical nature of ReOx sites on these catalysts, and demonstrates the remarkable activity of ReOx for the selective conversion of levulinic acid to GVL. Additionally, the selectivity at 90 % in the most active catalysts does not change in function of the LA conversion, such as shown in Fig. S6. In broader context, the best results from this study are compared to literature results of other catalytic systems, such as Ru/SiO2 [31], Pd–Cu/ZrO2 [30] and Cu/Al2O3 [3], among others (Table S1). The best LA conversion results were obtained on noble metals, such as Ru/C, Ru/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 (this work) catalysts. The non-nobles metal catalysts, such as Ni-MoOx/Al2O3 [18], Cu/Al2O3 [3] and CuO/WOx-Al2O3 [26] presented lower LA conversions and selectivities to GVL.The results from this work compares favorably to these reported results, which highlight the high potential of these catalysts for the transformation of levulinic acid to GVL. 4 Conclusion Rhenium oxide supported on ZrO2 and SiO2 were prepared with different loadings and tested for the conversion of levulinic acid. Catalytic activity, expressed as initial reaction rate, showed a similar trend for the two systems. The initial rate increased with Re loading, consistent with increased amount of active sites, but subsequently decreased at the highest loading due to loss of active sites through the formation of aggregates. Intrinsic rate revealed two distinct trends for the two systems. The intrinsic rate of the ZrO2-supported catalysts decreased with increasing Re loading. This behaviour was attributed to a higher interaction of ReOx with the ZrO2 support, decreasing the formation of oxygen vacancy, and probably disfavoring LA adsorption on active site with the increase of Re loading. In contrast, the intrinsic rate of the SiO2-supported catalysts did not show any dependency on Re loading, suggesting that the active sites (oxygen vacancy) were not affected by the SiO2 support. Products distribution was not influenced by Re loading or the type of support, and the catalysts displayed high selectivity towards GVL (>90 %). This reflects the exceptional potential of ReOx catalysts for the conversion of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone. Declaration of Competing Interest The authors report no declarations of interest. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of levulinic acid over rhenium oxide catalysts supported on ZrO2 and SiO2 in a batch reactor at 200 °C and 5 MPa of H2 pressure was studied. The catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation with nominal loadings of 5–18 wt.%. The catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption, field emission scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, H2-temperature programmed reduction, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The catalysts were highly active and selective to γ-valerolactone. Catalytic activity, expressed as initial reaction rate and based on catalyst weight, was correlated with dispersion. The difference in the activity trend was attributed to ReOx-support interaction: ZrO2 interacted more strongly with ReOx and modified the electronic character of the sites, whereas SiO2 interacted weakly with ReOx, leading to unmodified Re active sites, irrespective of Re loading. All the catalysts exceeded 90 % selectivity to GVL.
coredata.dc:title: Conversion of levulinic acid over rhenium oxide catalysts: Effect of metal content
